prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for shutting off the WiFi.
Our kids are good kids but don’t do enough around the house, particularly on housework day. Wifey & I are often still finishing after dark. Son (18) is also addicted to league of legends. He is 2nd year university and lives at home without paying for anything except his clothes, bus money & spending.

I (M49) got started about 8am this morning (Saturday). Didn’t feel very motivated because I’m in NZ, yesterday was the day 49 people were gunned down at their Mosques and Christchurch is my home town so I’m feeling pretty down. At about 9:30 I knocked on his door to ask if he could start on his jobs & empty the dishwasher. He was in a game & said yeah yeah.

No sign of him and an hour later my wife said she’d just asked him and he said he was in the middle of a game. She told him she’d get me to cut the wifi if he didn’t start helping and he said if she did that he wouldn’t be doing anything. (Once a game starts you can’t quit without risking a stand down for several days).

When I heard that I went straight to the router, disconnected the power cable & put it away. A minute or two later he starts yelling from downstairs. I went down there and he begins shouting and swearing at me (f***ing this & that). I told him calmly he had just lost internet until I decided to give it back & so of course he escalated the shouting. I went back upstairs feeling very bruised.

He was up within 5 mins, went to the fridge & got an apple. I told him if he was going to yell at me like that he can’t expect to eat my food and can buy his own. Even more shouting and swearing. Youngest daughter (11) tried to tell him to stop and got the brunt of it. She has OCD & Aspergers so can’t cope with that sort of thing and I sent her upstairs. Son threw the apple, kicked the washing basket over (talking a chip out of the coffee table) & stormed downstairs.

Ten minutes later I heard what sounded like a door slam over & over. When I went downstairs I saw the doorframe to his bedroom is split top to bottom. I told him he has to fix it.

Wife calmed things down & later he even washed her car. She drove him to work at 6pm by which stage we still hadn’t exchanged words. He’d already planned to stay at a friend’s so he’s probably getting plastered. It’s midnight now & wifey is worried because “he’s not in a good state of mind.” I can’t help worrying too. He’s not answering her texts.

I’m tossing up whether to (1) programme the router to exclude all his devices; and/or (2) take his bedroom door away. However at 18 he’s an adult. I don’t know whether ITA, HTA or NTA. 
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's break this down. The user wants to know if the author (the father) is in the wrong for cutting off the WiFi. The situation involves an 18-year-old son who's in university, living at home without paying much, and not doing his housework. The dad was feeling down after a traumatic event in his hometown and decided to cut the WiFi to get the son to help. The son reacted angrily, shouted, threw things, and damaged the doorframe. Now the dad is considering further actions like blocking the router for his devices or removing the door.

First, I need to assess whether cutting the WiFi is a reasonable action. The father's intention was to motivate the son to do his chores. However, the son was in the middle of a game, which he can't leave without consequences. The dad's action led to a confrontation where the son yelled and acted out. The father also took away the WiFi, which is a significant control measure. 

Considering that the son is 18 and an adult, even though he's living at home, the father's authority might be more about parental responsibility but also the son's independence. Cutting off WiFi could be seen as a harsh measure, especially if it's the only internet access and the son relies on it for communication or studies. However, the son's refusal to help with chores and the subsequent aggression might justify the father's frustration.

The father's actions led to immediate conflict. Using force to remove the WiFi might be seen as overstepping, especially if the son has a right to internet access. But on the other hand, the father is trying to enforce responsibility. The son's reaction was extreme, which complicates things. The father's decision to take away the WiFi was preemptive, but the son's response was violent, which the father might not have foreseen.

There's also the emotional state of the father, dealing with trauma from the mosque shootings. His motivation might be influenced by stress and a need to maintain household order. However, using drastic measures without communication could contribute to the conflict. The father might have considered other methods first, like a calm discussion or setting clear expectations.

The son's behavior was clearly unacceptable—he yelled, swore, threw things, and damaged property. The father's response to the damage (making him fix it) seems reasonable. But the initial WiFi cutoff might have been the trigger. The father might not be in the wrong if he's trying to enforce household responsibilities, but the method could be questioned. The son's age and autonomy play a role here. At 18, the son should have some independence, and the father's actions might infringe on that unless there's a mutual agreement on household rules.

In summary, while the father's intention was to enforce responsibility, the method of cutting off WiFi without prior discussion and the resulting conflict might put him in a wrong position. However, the son's subsequent aggressive behavior also complicates the matter. The father's actions were a response to the son's inaction and disrespect, but the approach could be seen as heavy-handed.
